case_vignette: A 60-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of sudden, painless loss of vision in her right eye that occurred 30 minutes ago while watching TV. She has coronary artery disease, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus; she has had trouble adhering to her medication regimen. Her blood pressure is 160/85 mm Hg. Examination shows 20/50 vision in the left eye and no perception of light in the right eye. Direct pupillary reflex is present in the left eye, but absent in the right eye. Accommodation is intact bilaterally. Intraocular pressure is 16 mm Hg in the left eye and 18 mm Hg in the right eye. Fundoscopic examination of the right eye shows a pale, white retina with a bright red area within the macula. The optic disc appears normal.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Neurology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I suddenly lost my vision in my right eye while I was watching TV about 30 minutes ago, and I can't see anything out of it now.
Are you experiencing any pain in your eye or around it?
No, I'm not feeling any pain in or around my eye.
Do you have any history of eye problems or any chronic diseases like diabetes or hypertension?
Yes, I have type 2 diabetes, high blood pressure, and also coronary artery disease.
Have you been diagnosed with any issues related to blood circulation or clotting in the past?
No, you have not asked me about any past diagnoses related to blood circulation or clotting.
Have you experienced any other symptoms like weakness, difficulty speaking, or numbness in any part of your body?
No, I have not experienced any of those symptoms.
Do you or any of your family members have a history of glaucoma or retinal detachment?
You didn't ask me about my family history before, so I didn't mention anything about glaucoma or retinal detachment.
Does your vision loss have any associated symptoms such as flashes of light or a curtain coming down over your vision?
No, there were no flashes of light or anything like a curtain coming down over my vision.
Do you have a history of migraine headaches?
You have not asked me about my history with headaches before, so I didn't mention anything about migraines.
Have you suffered from migraine headaches in the past?
No, I haven't suffered from migraine headaches in the past.

Given your sudden vision loss without pain or other neurological symptoms, and your history of diabetes, hypertension, and coronary artery disease:

**Final Diagnosis:** Painless Loss of Vision - Suspect Arteritic Anterior Ischemic Optic Neuropathy (AION) secondary to Giant Cell Arteritis (GCA) or Non-Arteritic Anterior Ischemic Optic Neuropathy (NAION) associated with vascular risk factors.

No, I haven't had any recent injuries or surgery.
**Final Diagnosis:** Sudden complete vision loss in one eye without pain, in a patient with high blood pressure, diabetes, and coronary artery disease, is suggestive of retinal artery occlusion.
